snippet: A nearly complete skeleton of a creature that weighed less than an ounce dials back the primate fossil record by eight million years, paleontologists report.
abstract: Paleontologists report in journal Nature finding nearly complete skeleton of tiny, ancient primate--creature that weighed less than an ounce, had a tail longer than its body and would fit in the palm of one's hand--that is earliest well-preserved fossil primate ever found, dating back some 55 million years and dialing back the fossil record for primates by an impressive eight million years.
lead_paragraph: A nearly complete skeleton of a creature that weighed less than an ounce dials back the primate fossil record by eight million years, paleontologists report.

headline.main: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates’ Clock, Scientists Say
headline.print_headline: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates’ Clock, Scientists Say
